notes: Second-generation Mazda3 with updated styling and improved dynamics. MazdaSpeed3 performance variant available with 2.3L turbo engine (263 hp) until 2013. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda3 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation Mazda3 introduces SkyActiv technology with improved fuel efficiency and performance. Kodo 'Soul of Motion' design language. No turbocharged variant offered in this generation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda3 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Mazda6 midsize sedan. V6 engine optional on higher trims. Final generation before SkyActiv technology introduction. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda6 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation Mazda6 features SkyActiv technology and Kodo design. Turbo engine added for 2018 model year. Manual transmission availability limited to early years. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda6 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation Mazda2 subcompact offered in North America from 2011-2014. Discontinued after 2014 model year. Replaced briefly by Scion iA/Toyota Yaris iA sedan based on Mazda2 platform. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda2 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Tribute compact SUV based on Ford Escape/Mercury Mariner CD2 platform. Hybrid variant available with 2.5L Atkinson-cycle engine and electric motor (153 hp combined). Final years before discontinuation. Difficulty modifier reflects hybrid system complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda Tribute article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Midsize crossover with sporty styling. Turbocharged engine standard on early models, naturally aspirated 2.5L added for 2010+. Discontinued after 2012 model year in North America. Difficulty modifier reflects turbo maintenance complexity. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-7 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation CX-9 three-row crossover with V6 engine. Shares Ford CD3 platform with Ford Edge and Lincoln MKX. Received facelift for 2010 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-9 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation CX-9 features SkyActiv technology and downsized turbocharged four-cylinder replacing V6. Lighter weight and improved fuel efficiency. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-9 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

First-generation CX-5 is first Mazda vehicle to feature full SkyActiv technology suite including engines, transmissions, body, and chassis. Replaced Tribute as compact crossover offering. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation CX-5 with refined SkyActiv technology and premium interior. Turbocharged engine optional starting 2019 model year. Most popular Mazda model in North America. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.
Subcompact crossover SUV based on Mazda2 platform. Sold in North America from 2016-2021. Replaced by CX-30 in 2020. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-3 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Subcompact crossover SUV introduced for 2020 model year (late 2019). Built on SkyActiv-Vehicle Architecture. Positioned between CX-3 and CX-5. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda CX-30 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Second-generation Mazda5 compact minivan with sliding rear doors. Six-passenger seating in three rows. Discontinued in North America after 2015 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sports car with 1.3L Renesis twin-rotor Wankel rotary engine. Features unique freestyle doors (rear-hinged rear doors). Final years in North America before discontinuation. High difficulty modifier reflects specialized rotary engine maintenance including apex seal replacement, oil consumption monitoring, and compression testing requirements. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda RX-8 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Third-generation MX-5 Miata with available power retractable hardtop (PRHT). Received facelift for 2009 model year. Larger and heavier than previous generations. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fourth-generation MX-5 Miata with SkyActiv technology. Lighter weight and improved dynamics compared to NC. RF (Retractable Fastback) variant with power hardtop added for 2017. Power increased to 181 hp for 2019+ models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mazda MX-5 article, December 19, 2024 revision.
